45 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
46 // GPSTk includes
47 #include "Matrix.hpp"
48 #include "geometry.hpp" // DEG_TO_RAD
49 #include "GNSSconstants.hpp" // TWO_PI
50 // geomatics
51 #include "PhaseWindup.hpp"
52 #include "SunEarthSatGeometry.hpp"
53 #include <math.h>
54 
55 using namespace std;
56 
57 namespace gpstk
58 {
59 
60 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
61 // Compute the phase windup, in cycles, given the time, the unit vector from receiver
62 // to transmitter, and the west and north unit vectors at the receiver, all in ECEF.
63 // YR is the West unit vector, XR is the North unit vector, at the receiver.
64 // shadow is the fraction of the sun's area not visible at the satellite.
65 // Previous value is needed to ensure continuity and prevent 1-cycle ambiguities.
66 double PhaseWindup(double& prev, // previous return value
67  CommonTime& tt, // epoch of interest
68  Position& SV, // satellite position
69  Position& Rx2Tx, // unit vector from receiver to satellite
70  Position& YR, // west unit vector at receiver
71  Position& XR, // north unit vector at receiver
72  SolarSystem& SSEph, // solar system ephemeris
73  EarthOrientation& EO, // earth orientation at tt
74  double& shadow, // fraction of sun not visible at satellite
75  bool isBlockR) // true for Block IIR satellites
76  throw(Exception)
77 {
78 try {
79  double d,windup;
80  Position DR,DT;
81  Position TR = -1.0 * Rx2Tx; // transmitter to receiver
82 
83  // get satellite attitude
84  Position XT,YT,ZT;
85  Matrix<double> Att = SatelliteAttitude(tt, SV, SSEph, EO, shadow);
86  XT = Position(Att(0,0),Att(0,1),Att(0,2)); // Cartesian is default
87  YT = Position(Att(1,0),Att(1,1),Att(1,2));
88  ZT = Position(Att(2,0),Att(2,1),Att(2,2));
89 
90  // NB. Block IIR has X (ie the effective dipole orientation) in the -XT direction.
91  // Ref. Kouba(2009) GPS Solutions 13, pp1-12.
92  // In fact it should be a rotation by pi about Z, producing a constant offset.
93  //if(isBlockR)
94  //{
95  // XT = Position(-Att(0,0),-Att(0,1),-Att(0,2));
96  // YT = Position(-Att(1,0),-Att(1,1),-Att(1,2));
97  //}
98 
99  // compute effective dipoles at receiver and transmitter
100  // Ref Kouba(2009) Using IGS Products; note sign diff. <=> East(ref) West(here)
101  // NB. switching second sign between the two eqns <=> overall sign windup
102  DR = XR - TR * TR.dot(XR) + Position(TR.cross(YR));
103  DT = XT - TR * TR.dot(XT) - Position(TR.cross(YT));
104 
105  // normalize
106  d = 1.0/DR.mag();
107  DR = d * DR;
108  d = 1.0/DT.mag();
109  DT = d * DT;
110 
111  windup = ::acos(DT.dot(DR)) / TWO_PI; // cycles
112  if (TR.dot(DR.cross(DT)) < 0.) windup *= -1.0;
113 
114  // adjust by 2pi if necessary
115  d = windup-prev;
116  windup -= int(d + (d < 0.0 ? -0.5 : 0.5));
117 
118  return windup;
119 }
120 catch(Exception& e) { GPSTK_RETHROW(e); }
121 catch(exception& e) { Exception E("std except: "+string(e.what())); GPSTK_THROW(E); }
122 catch(...) { Exception e("Unknown exception"); GPSTK_THROW(e); }
123 }
124 
125 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
126 // Version without JPL solar system ephemeris - uses a lower quality solar position.
127 // Compute the phase windup, in cycles, given the time, the unit vector from receiver
128 // to transmitter, and the west and north unit vectors at the receiver, all in ECEF.
129 // YR is the West unit vector, XR is the North unit vector, at the receiver.
130 // shadow is the fraction of the sun's area not visible at the satellite.
131 double PhaseWindup(double& prev, // previous return value
132  CommonTime& tt, // epoch of interest
133  Position& SV, // satellite position
134  Position& Rx2Tx, // unit vector from receiver to satellite
135  Position& YR, // west unit vector at receiver
136  Position& XR, // north unit vector at receiver
137  double& shadow, // fraction of sun not visible at satellite
138  bool isBlockR) // true for Block IIR satellites
139  throw(Exception)
140 {
141 try {
142  double d,windup=0.0;
143  Position DR,DT;
144  Position TR = -1.0 * Rx2Tx; // transmitter to receiver
145 
146  // get satellite attitude
147  Position XT,YT,ZT;
148  Matrix<double> Att = SatelliteAttitude(tt, SV, shadow);
149  XT = Position(Att(0,0),Att(0,1),Att(0,2)); // Cartesian is default
150  YT = Position(Att(1,0),Att(1,1),Att(1,2));
151  ZT = Position(Att(2,0),Att(2,1),Att(2,2));
152 
153  // NB. Block IIR has X (ie the effective dipole orientation) in the -XT direction.
154  // Ref. Kouba(2009) GPS Solutions 13, pp1-12.
155  if(isBlockR) XT = Position(-Att(0,0),-Att(0,1),-Att(0,2));
156 
157  // compute effective dipoles at receiver and transmitter
158  // Ref Kouba(2009) Using IGS Products; note sign diff. <=> East(ref) West(here)
159  // NB. switching second sign between the two eqns <=> overall sign windup
160  DR = XR - TR * TR.dot(XR) + Position(TR.cross(YR));
161  DT = XT - TR * TR.dot(XT) - Position(TR.cross(YT));
162 
163  // normalize
164  d = 1.0/DR.mag();
165  DR = d * DR;
166  d = 1.0/DT.mag();
167  DT = d * DT;
168 
169  windup = ::acos(DT.dot(DR)) / TWO_PI;
170  if (TR.dot(DR.cross(DT)) < 0.) windup *= -1.0;
171 
172  // adjust by 2pi if necessary
173  d = windup-prev;
174  windup -= int(d + (d < 0.0 ? -0.5 : 0.5));
175 
176  return windup;
177 }
178 catch(Exception& e) { GPSTK_RETHROW(e); }
179 catch(exception& e) { Exception E("std except: "+string(e.what())); GPSTK_THROW(E); }
180 catch(...) { Exception e("Unknown exception"); GPSTK_THROW(e); }
181 }
182 
183 
184 } // end namespace gpstk
